name: Lending club default predictions
tagline: A chronicle of our analysis of Lending Club data.
body:
# Lending Rate Default Predictions
_Arthur Aguillar, Dwijo Goswami and James Fallon_

## Data exploration

Our task was to predict loan defaults using data provided by [Lending Club](https://www.lendingclub.com), a peer to peer lending service. The organization makes de-identified loan [data](https://www.lendingclub.com/info/download-data.action) available publicly. 

We began by exploring the loan data. We categorized loans into those currently in delinquency or default (risky loans) and those with no payment violations (not risky loans).   
Initially, we wanted to explore some basic relationships. In the first instance, we were interested in how poorly loans had performed based on when they were issued.  

![](https://thefaulters.github.io/Lending-Club-Default-Predictions/Images/Loans-delinquency-bar.png)

Additionally, we were interested in whether higher risk borrowers (those with lower grades) consistently had to pay higher interest rates (and whether they indeed defaulted more often). We also wanted to make sure to account for imbalance in the dataset - since most borrowers don't default.  
 
![](https://thefaulters.github.io/Lending-Club-Default-Predictions/Images/Risk.png) ![](https://thefaulters.github.io/Lending-Club-Default-Predictions/Images/Imbalance.png)
